bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Wallach to J. F. Siler, September 18, 1950

div1.p: Wallach sends his condolences for the death of Kean. He is dismayed at waiting until the end of November to discuss a commemorative program for Reed and offers to visit Washington to discuss the subject.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Wallach to J. F. Siler, September 18, 1950
div1.opener:
September 18, 1950
Col. J. F. Siler, U.S.A.
2220 - 20th Street, N.W.
Washington 9, D. C.
Dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of September 12th. I am very sorry
to learn about the death of your president and want to extend to
you and to your associates my sincere condolences.

I note with some dismay your thought about postponing our meeting
until the latter part of November. Since the matter that we have
in mind is of some imminence, I think it might be worthwhile for us
to meet in advance of that date.

I should be glad to come down to Washington to lay the whole subject
before you in full since I believe that it can bring nothing but
gratifying results to the Walter Reed Memorial Association and to
the task that it has set itself.
